statement.text: Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) is a syndrome of ambulatory venous hypertension from impaired venous return, caused by valvular incompetence (reflux) and/or venous obstruction. It manifests as varicose veins, edema, skin changes (hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis), and venous ulceration. The CEAP classification provides standardized description.
statement.formal: CVI: Ambulatory venous hypertension from reflux ± obstruction; Spectrum: varicose veins → edema → skin changes → ulcer; CEAP classification: Clinical-Etiologic-Anatomic-Pathophysiologic

explanation.intuition: Veins have one-way valves that keep blood flowing toward the heart, against gravity when standing. When these valves fail (from genetics, prior clot, or just wear and tear), blood falls back down and pools in the legs. Over time, this backward flow and pooling damages the smallest blood vessels, causing fluid to leak into tissues and chronic inflammation that leads to skin damage and eventually ulcers.
explanation.key_insight: CVI is extremely common, affecting up to 50% of adults to some degree. While often considered cosmetic (varicose veins), advanced CVI causes significant morbidity and affects quality of life. Venous ulcers heal slowly and frequently recur without addressing the underlying venous hypertension.
explanation.technical_details: Venous hypertension in CVI typically >80 mmHg (normal ambulatory venous pressure 20-30 mmHg with calf muscle pump). Superficial reflux (saphenous) is most common and most treatable. Deep vein reflux and obstruction (post-thrombotic) are harder to treat. Perforator vein incompetence transmits high deep system pressures to superficial system.

clinical_C.C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: Gold standard - assess reflux (>0.5 sec reversed flow) and obstruction
diagnosis.vcss: Venous Clinical Severity Score for outcomes tracking

interventional_superficial.endovenous_ablation: Laser (EVLA), radiofrequency (RFA) - first-line for saphenous reflux
interventional_superficial.sclerotherapy: Chemical ablation - for reticular veins, varicosities

ulcer_management.intervention: Correct superficial reflux to promote healing and prevent recurrence

definition.@value: Syndrome of ambulatory venous hypertension from valvular incompetence causing varicose veins, skin changes, and ulceration

clinical_pearls: CEAP C6 = active ulcer; C5 = healed ulcer
Compression is cornerstone of ALL CVI treatment - even with intervention
Endovenous ablation (laser/RF) has replaced surgery for most saphenous reflux
Venous ulcers are typically at medial malleolus (arterial ulcers are more distal)
